div.head: Section 1
div.p: For the response to this question, it must first be presupposed that there was a custom among the ancients, not only among the nations who were lacking knowledge of the true God, but also among the faithful worshippers of the true God himself: Kings and nobles would place whatever precious things they had in life with themselves after death in their tombs. And the greater and richer the things that were placed in their tombs, the more they excelled others in power and were wealthier in riches. For through this their glory and magnificence were rendered more illustrious in the memory of men in future ages.

This is clear from that passage in Job 3
As those digging for treasure, they rejoice vehemently when they have found a tomb . And in Baruch chapter 6:
Or as to a tomb with a dead man brought in: so the priests guard the doors with locks and bars lest they be despoiled by thieves
(namely, the treasures) stored there with the dead. Thus the gloss says:
In ancient times (it says) precious things were placed in the tombs of the powerful, on account of which they were shut strongly and with diligence lest they be extracted by thieves , thus far that passage.
Saint Thomas says the same on Job in the cited place .

Likewise it appears from the example of the magnificent King Solomon who buried his father David in Jerusalem most fittingly with other things and ceremonies which are customarily administered around funerals. And he stored many riches with him. For he had made for him an honorable tomb around which he established seven treasury chambers which he filled with gold and precious stones. The magnitude of these riches is manifestly shown through those things which were afterwards extracted from David's tomb. For after a time of thirteen hundred years, Hyrcanus the high priest, while the city of Jerusalem was being besieged by King Antiochus, wishing to give him money so that he would withdraw from the siege and take away his army, not having the means to fulfill this, opened one chamber of David's tomb and, having taken from there three thousand talents, gave part to Antiochus and thus removed the anxiety of the siege.

Now of talents, as the Master says in the histories, there were three kinds, namely the least, the greater, and the greatest. For the least was fifty pounds in weight; the greater seventy pounds; but the greatest one hundred twenty pounds. Moreover, each pound was worth fifty gold pieces. Whence it is clear that even if each of the talents were of the least kind, still three thousand talents amounted to a great sum of gold pieces. Rather, if they were of the greatest kind, as seems reasonable...

After these things, however, much time having passed, again King Herod, hearing that Hyrcanus the king before him had opened the tomb of David and found three thousand talents, believing much more was deposited and would suffice for all his expenses, opening the tomb entered by night since he did not wish the city to know of this. Therefore taking only his most faithful friends, he did not find the deposited money as Hyrcanus had, but he took ornaments and many golden vessels. But while he applied all diligence and made more careful investigation and wished to enter further to the tombs in which the bodies of David and Solomon were placed, two of his guards were consumed by flames coming from within. Then he, terrified with fear, went out. Never afterwards was there anyone who could find the other chambers, although great treasures in the tomb of David and Solomon are believed to exist even to this day. For it was done by magic so that it would not be permitted to anyone either to find or, if they found, to be able to take anything from there. All these things Josephus relates in book 7 chapter 16 and book 13 chapter 18 and book 16 chapter 7 of the Jewish Antiquities.

Moved by the fame of these things, the Turk named Suleiman in our times, namely around the year of our Lord 1520, when he captured Jerusalem, sought the treasures in David's tomb with great diligence, but he was never able to find them, as is read in the history of the Turks. The reason for this frustration is that such chambers were hidden under the earth in a mechanical way, that is, by magic, so that to those entering the monument they could in no way be manifest, as Josephus says.

It is clear therefore that to store treasures and other precious things with themselves in their tombs was a thing licit and customary among the ancients, whether faithful or unfaithful, common and general. And the reason for this can be assigned as follows: the natural inclination which is in all men insofar as they are rational, that due honor be preserved to human nature above other animals, namely that the human body be buried (that is) that it have this honor, because just as among all animals man alone is a sacred and divine animal, so to him alone is this honor granted that his corpse be buried lest it be torn apart by birds and other animals, while the corpses of others remain unburied. Whence the Philosopher in Rhetoric I places burial among the other parts of honor.

Moreover, there is a certain honorable good for the dead insofar as they live in the memories of men, that their bodies be buried. For all think there is nothing by which we do greater injury to the dead than if we drag his body through the earth and give it to dogs and beasts to devour. Thus it is gathered from
Aristotle in Ethics 5 when he speaks of one who kills himself, whether he does injustice to himself. And he responds that no, but to the city. And therefore the city or community inflicts punishment on him, namely dishonor concerning the body, namely that it causes the corpse to be dragged through the earth or that it remain unburied. Therefore it must be said that a certain evil comes to the dead from the fact that they are not buried. For they are considered unhappy who lack burial. On the contrary, however, good comes to the dead from the fact that they are buried honorably. Thus it is clear in Isaiah 11 where many honorable things are said about Moses and afterwards it is added about the honor of his tomb: his tomb will be glorious. And yet if glory and honor of the tomb did not pertain to Christ, nothing would be said prophetically about this. Therefore the glory of the tomb pertained to Christ. Therefore some good happens to the dead if their bodies are committed to burial, insofar as they have being and a way of living in the opinions of men. From this therefore there arose among all nations this natural conception: that the bodies of the deceased should be buried or cremated. Those who decreed cremation preserved the ashes and kept them in tombs or in some distinguished and honorable and eminent place. Just as the ashes of Julius Caesar to this day in Rome upon a certain huge stone of pyramidal shape which is called a needle behind the church of Saint Peter are said to remain. For the ancients judged, and also the moderns, it to be shameful and injurious that human bodies should remain unburied. And on account of this we see men solicitous in life about constructing tombs and funeral rites and other things pertaining to them. And the more powerful and wealthy they are in riches, the more honorable, beautiful, and expensive they prepare tombs for themselves. Whence one and the same principal thing which most brings honor to the deceased and so that their names may possess possible immortality among posterity, in that way by which they have being and live in the memories of men, seems to be the tomb, especially if it has been built from precious material and very expensively and with subtle and optimal workmanship, adorned moreover with most beautiful and precious other fitting things, and far more especially if with human corpses great wealth and precious treasures are placed in tombs.

But because among kings and the powerful in the world such magnitude and opulence of riches is easily found, by this the more their glory, power, and royal excellence grew and increased and was made known to future ages: the more treasures and riches of gold and silver and precious stones and other diverse furnishings of great value they ordered to be stored with themselves in their tombs or to be buried with them.
